clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of PIOMI on Oral Feeding of the Premature Infants
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of the Premature Infant Oral Motor Intervention on the Oral Feeding Skills of the Premature Infants: A Randomized Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

clinical_study.source: Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda, Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico

brief_summary.textblock: Randomized controlled clinical trial aimed at evaluating the effects of the "Premature infant oral motor intervention" method on the oral feeding skills of the premature infants.

detailed_description.textblock: Numerous evidences emerge from the literature review on the usefulness of the PIOMI method to improve food skills in the premature infant. The goal of this study is to evaluate the effects of the PIOMI method by adding the gustatory stimulation to the original protocol.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: RCT characterized by the comparison between two groups (treated / untreated)

secondary_outcome.description: oral intake at day one and at day three
PMA on reaching full oral feeding
transition times from the tube to full oral feeding

arm_group.description: Patients in this group will receive the intraoral and extraoral stimulations provided by the PIOMI protocol. These stimulations will last 5 minutes and will be performed once a day for 7 consecutive days for each patient.
Patients in this group will receive classic care.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- gestational age at birth between 25-33 weeks;
- clinical stability;
- possible presence of nasogastric or oro-gastric tube;
- non-invasive respiratory support (oxygen, high flows)
Exclusion Criteria:
- gestational age <25 weeks or> 33 weeks
- absence of clinical stability
- invasive respiratory support (CPAP)
- previous surgical interventions
- ongoing infections
- congenital and / or chromosomal diseases
- brain, metabolic, cardiac, gastrointestinal diseases
- presence of bronchopulmonary dysplasia
